root: ^Anger is a powerful emotion, my child. It can build or destroy, depending on how you handle it. What do you do when you feel angry?

s: ^I try to calm myself down before reacting.
^I just let it out, even if it hurts others.
^I bottle it up and deal with it later.

Calm_Before_Reacting: ^That’s wise. Taking a moment to breathe can stop anger from controlling you. What helps you calm down the most?

s: ^I take a walk or step away from the situation.
^I talk to someone I trust about how I’m feeling.

Step_Away: ^Walking away is a sign of strength, not weakness. It shows you’re in control of your emotions.
Talk_To_Someone: ^Sharing your feelings can lighten the load. It’s good to have someone you trust to lean on.
Let_It_Out: ^Anger is natural, but letting it out without thinking can hurt you and those around you. Why do you feel the need to release it so quickly?

s: ^It feels like the only way to make people listen to me.
^I don’t know. I just can’t keep it in.

Make_People_Listen: ^I understand, but there are better ways to make people hear you. Calm words often speak louder than shouting.
Cant_Keep_It_In: ^It’s hard to hold in strong emotions, but learning to control them will help you in the long run.
Bottle_It_Up: ^Bottling up your anger might seem easier, but it can build up and explode later. Why do you keep it inside?

s: ^I don’t want to hurt others, so I keep it to myself.
^I feel like no one will understand how I’m feeling.

Dont_Want_To_Hurt: ^That’s thoughtful of you, but you need to find a healthy way to release it. Anger, when bottled up, can hurt you most of all.
No_One_Understands: ^Even if it feels that way, someone will always care enough to listen. Don’t carry that weight alone.
